title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The term "article of fur" in this Act refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The definition of furskin, raw or dressed, is based on the Tariff Schedules of the United States. The term "interstate or foreign commerce" is also defined within the Act. The terms "furskin", "raw or not dressed", and "dressed" are defined based on the Tariff Schedules of the United States. The term "interstate or foreign commerce" is also defined within the Act. The term "import" means to bring into the United States. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and federal entities. The term "person" includes any individual, partnership, association, corporation, trust, officer, employee, agent, department, or entity subject to US jurisdiction. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" denotes a specific type of trap. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" refers to a spring-powered device with two steel jaws designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb. The term "Secretary" in this context means the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. No fur article can be traded if it comes from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or ship fur in violation of this rule, as well as to transport steel jaw leghold traps across state or international borders. Additionally, it is unlawful to buy or sell traps that have been transported in violation of this regulation. It is illegal to transport, sell, or purchase steel jaw leghold traps across state or international borders. Violating this regulation or any related regulations can result in fines upon conviction. Any person who knowingly violates regulations regarding the transportation, sale, or purchase of steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to two years for subsequent offenses. The Secretary will reward individuals with half of the fine paid for providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act is outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges can issue warrants for enforcement within their jurisdictions. Federal officials can assist in enforcement to the maximum extent permitted by law. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement within their jurisdictions. Individuals with enforcement authority can detain, search, seize, and make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act. Individuals with enforcement authority under the Act may detain, search, seize, and make arrests without a warrant for violations. They can also execute warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Items seized will be held by authorized persons. Authorized individuals can make arrests without a warrant for violations of the Act and execute warrants issued by judges. Seized items will be held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. Items seized under the Act will be held by authorized individuals pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond instead of holding the item. Upon forfeiture to the United States, the item will be disposed of as prescribed by the Secretary. Any fur or steel jaw leghold trap taken, possessed, sold, transported, or imported against the Act will be forfeited to the United States. The Secretary will dispose of forfeited items in a manner consistent with the Act's purposes. Any article of fur or steel jaw leghold trap found in violation of the Act or its regulations will be subject to forfeiture to the United States. The Attorney General may seek to enjoin individuals violating the Act or its regulations. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, which will take effect one year after its enactment.
